ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

ROV ENFORCEMENT SQUAD
(Particulars)


    1. Mr J. F. Conceicao asked the Minister for Communications what the actual strength is, in terms of personnel and machines, of the Enforcement Squad of the Registry of Vehicles, and whether it is sufficient for current traffic conditions.

    The Minister of State for Communications (Dr Ang Kok Peng) (for the Minister for Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, a total strength of 80 men is provided for the Enforcement Squad for this financial year (1972-73). At the moment, the Enforcement Squad is functioning with 32 men. Details of the number of authorised posts available for this year and the number of posts filled so far are as follows: 

    Post                 Number of        Posts filled

                    of Authorised Posts      to-date

                        (1972/1973)  

Asst.Superintendent 

    of Police                1                  1

Inspector                    1                  1

Staff Sergeants              2                  -

Sergeants                    4                  2

Corporals                   12                  -

Constables                  60                 28

                            --                 --   

                            80                 32

                            ==                 ==


Many of the posts are vacant due to difficulty in recruitment faced by the Police Force. The posts of Staff Sergeants and Corporals are to be regarded in line with the recommendations of the Lee Soo Ann Report on the Police Force.

    The ROV Enforcement Squad has a fleet of 40 motor-cycles, which is the number authorised for this financial year.

    The ROV Enforcement Squad is a supplementary force to the Mobile Squad of the Traffic Police. It was established primarily to deal with offences relating to the duties and responsibilities of the ROV. These include monitoring the conduct and behaviour

Column: 359

of operators of public service vehicles, dealing with road tax offences and other enforcement action as well as assisting in the implementation of certain policies recommended in the White Paper on "Reorganisation of the Motor Transport Service of Singapore" (Command Paper 21 of 1970).

    If all the vacant posts could be filled, the force of 80 men and 40 motor-cycles would be sufficient. However, in spite of the shortage of manpower, every effort is being made to see that the Squad functions as efficiently as possible. In the month of September, for instance, a total of 765 vehicles were interdicted by the ROV for the following offences:

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Sir, will the Minister of State for Communications consider the staggering of office hours to ease traffic congestion in the city area?

    Dr Ang Kok Peng: Sir, to some extent, office hours in the city area have already been staggered. Perhaps a greater measure of it would help to ease the traffic.

    Mr J. F. Conceicao (Katong): Mr Speaker, Sir, would the Minister of State not agree that, in respect of monitoring the conduct and behaviour of operators of public service vehicles, an expeditious increase in the present corps of ROV personnel would serve to act as a disciplinary measure against the behaviour of bus operators, especially along public roads?

Column: 360



    Dr Ang Kok Peng: Since the Member for Katong has mentioned the behaviour of public bus operators, which leaves much to be desired, let me say that we have been trying our best to solve this problem, and a certain amount of measure has been taken. Recently we have introduced a nation-wide campaign to encourage road courtesy, with greater emphasis on road safety.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister of State if he would inform this House as to the criterion adopted by the Ministry in judging the efficiency of the personnel attached to the ROV. I hope it is not based just on the number of summonses issued!

    Dr Ang Kok Peng: As I have pointed out in my answer, we are actually operating with 32 men out of an authorised strength of 80, from the efforts put in by these 32 men in keeping order on our roads, one could grant that there is efficiency in this Force.

    Mr Conceicao: In view of the sterling efforts that have been shown by the 32 men, would it not be better if we have the full complement of this Enforcement Squad as early as possible, and will the Ministry make all efforts to see that this complement is reached?

    Dr Ang Kok Peng: The difficulty of recruitment into this Enforcement Squad is something that is beyond our control. This problem is also faced by the Police Force as a whole. It is, of course, desirable that we get our full complement of officers as soon as possible.

Column: 360

TRAFFIC POLICE MOBILE SQUAD
(Particulars)


    2. Mr J. F. Conceicao asked the Minister for Health and Home Affairs what the actual strength is, in terms of personnel and machines, of the Mobile Squad of the Traffic Police, and whether it is sufficient for current traffic conditions.

Column: 361



    The Minister for Health and Home Affairs (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Mobile Squad of the Traffic Police has a total strength of 155 officers and 89 motor-cycles. Action is being taken to increase the number of personnel and machines to the authorised strength of 184 officers and 164 motor-cycles. The Mobile Squad at full strength should be able to cope with current traffic conditions.

    Mr Conceicao: May I ask a rather hoary question as to when the full strength will be achieved?

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Vacancies with regard to personnel are mainly due to retirement or resignation of officers. Recruitment exercises are now being carried out to fill them.

    Mr Conceicao: Sir, can the Mobile Squad motor-cycles be equipped at least with radio communications, so that this would improve the control of traffic on the roads?

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Of course, the Traffic Police welcomes more up-to-date equipment, so that they can be more efficient and more effective. We will discuss the matter with the other ministries with a view to getting more up-to-date equipment.

Column: 361

IMMIGRATION DEPARTMENT
(Public relations)


    3. Dr Tan Eng Liang asked the Minister for Health and Home Affairs if he will look into the cultivation of proper attitudes of the staff of the Immigration Department in their dealings with the public.

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, all Immigration staff on recruitment undergo training for a period ranging from one to four weeks before they are deployed at the various offices and check-points. During the training they are instructed among other things to be courteous and helpful to members of the public, as they are working in a department which has constant dealings with the public.

Column: 362



    Serving members of the Immigration staff are regularly reminded to be courteous and polite in dealing with the public. Departmental circulars on courtesy and correct attitude towards the public have been issued from time to time. Since June last year, seven such circulars were issued and the latest one was issued on the 18th October, 1972. Further, senior officers of the Department from time to time give lectures and briefings to the staff that their rudeness to the public will not be tolerated. There were occasions when disciplinary action was taken against members of the staff for being discourteous to the public. A Deputy Assistant Controller of Immigration, a Division II officer, was dismissed in 1969 for being rude to a member of the public.

    Members of the public who know of specific instances of discourtesy or rudeness by any of the Immigration staff are invited to write to my Ministry, giving details. Immediate investigations will be instituted and appropriate action taken, including dismissal wherever necessary. However, general allegations of discourtesy without giving specific details will not be helpful.

Column: 362

REGISTRY OF COMPANIES
(Improvement measures)


    4. Dr Tan Eng Liang asked the Minister for Finance if he will consider taking measures to improve the workings and efficiency of the Registry of Companies as the watch-dog and supervisory body under the Companies Act.

    The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Sir, I am always ready to consider measures to improve the working and efficiency of the Registry of Companies as I am with any other Department in my Ministry. Perhaps the hon. Member would indicate or write to me indicating the deficiencies that he considers should be remedied.

    Dr Tan Eng Liang (River Valley): Sir, I shall be happy to supply the Minister with the necessary information.

CONSTITUTION (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

2.50 p.m.

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Mr Speaker, Sir, there is a need to increase the membership of the Public Service Commission because of the increased workload placed on the Members of the Commission. The Commission meets weekly. The Members also have to act as chairmen of Selection Boards which deal with the recruitment and promotion of civil servants and, sometimes, employees of statutory boards. A Member may have to attend at least three meetings in a week in his capacity as chairman of a Selection Board. In addition to these duties, each Member may be delegated certain powers to decide on matters relating to the recruitment, confirmation, promotion and disciplinary control of civil servants. These matters take up a lot of time.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time and committed to a Committee of the whole House.

    The House immediately resolved itself into a Committee on the Bill. -[Mr E. W. Barker].

    Bill considered in Committee; reported without amendment; read a Third time and passed.

Column: 364

PARLIAMENTARY ELECTIONS (TEMPORARY PROVISIONS)
BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

2.52 p.m.

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Sir, section 15 of the Parliamentary Elections Act requires the electoral registers for each electoral division to be revised annually before the 31st of

Column: 365

December in each year, or such later date as the Minister may appoint. The revision of the electoral registers for the year 1971 was completed in May 1972, and we went to the polls on the 2nd September last. It is unlikely that any by-election will be held before the end of this year and, for reasons of economy, it is proposed to dispense with the revision of the electoral registers for the year 1972.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time and committed to a Committee of the whole House.

    The House immediately resolved itself into a Committee on the Bill. -[Mr Barker].

    Bill considered in Committee; reported without amendment; read a Third time and passed.

Column: 365

PENSIONS (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

2.54 p.m.

    The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Honourable Members will recall that a 13th month salary was paid to civil servants in March this year. In fact, for reasons which I have already stated in this House, a second 13th month salary, which will otherwise be paid in March next year, will be paid in December of this year instead. This payment is intended to be an annual non-pensionable allowance, an allowance which would attract a Central Provident Fund contribution at the revised rate of 12 per cent. At the same time, because of the increase in the CPF rate from 10 per cent to 12 per cent, all pensionable employees in the Government service were required to make a two per cent CPF contribution with effect from April 1972 on their monthly emoluments, with a matching contribution from the Government. These contributions to the CPF are intended as additional benefits `over and above the pension benefits.

Column: 366



    As the Pensions Act stands, any period of service during which a Government employee was a member of the Central Provident Fund cannot be reckoned for benefits under the Pensions Act, unless he first pays back to the Government any CPF contributions made by the Government on his behalf. This is a requirement under section 60 (I) of the Act. In view of the changed circumstances since April 1972, when pensionable employees were required to contribute two per cent of their emoluments to the Central Provident Fund in respect of their pensionable service, it is necessary to amend section 6 of the Pensions Act. This amendment will allow a pensionable employee to retain the two per cent CPF contribution paid by Government on his account when he eventually retires from the service.

    Section 16 of the Act is also similarly affected, and a consequential amendment is required. This section provides for the payment of a death gratuity when an officer dies in service, or within one year of his retirement. The amending Bill, when passed, is to be made retroactive from 1st April, 1972, which is the date on which contributions to the Central Provident Fund were made for pensionable Government employees.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time and committed to a Committee of the whole House.

    The House immediately resolved itself into a Committee on the Bill.-[Mr Hon Sui Sen].

    Bill considered in Committee; reported without amendment; read a Third time and passed.

Column: 366

INDUSTRIAL TRAINING BOARD BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

3.00 p.m.

    The Minister for Education (Dr Lee Chiaw Meng): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

Column: 367



    Sir, in 1959 when the Government embarked on transferring Singapore's economy on to an industrial base, we determined that the large proportion of the workforce would in due course be industrially employed. This meant that the development of a skilled industrial workforce would assume growing importance, as Singapore's national income became increasingly dependent on the output and productivity of industry. Industrial training has therefore been recognised as a major instrument of economic policy.

    Thus, as a matter of national urgency, the National Industrial Training Council was established in April 1968 to deal with the immediate problem of developing and co-ordinating technical education and industrial training to meet this need. Two months later the Technical Education Department was specially formed within the Ministry of Education to execute the targets established by the Council. In the short space of four years, the Technical Education Department has substantially achieved the initial targets set out and laid a firm foundation for the development of a skilled industrial workforce.

    Sir, I should like, at this juncture, to correct certain mis-impressions about our vocational institute graduates and the value of the training they have received, which would otherwise undermine what has so far been accomplished.

    Before the new vocational institutes were established, the main supply of workers with any vocational training at all came from the vocational schools. Because of the similar name, vocational institutes have often been confused with vocational schools, which now no longer exist. This confusion is most unfortunate. Admittedly, many former vocational school students were drop-outs from the school system. The vocational institutes, on the other hand, cater for those with a reasonably high level of education who wish to learn a practical skill. Industries show a distinct preference for these graduates. The value of their

Column: 368

training has also been recognised by the Public Service Commission.

    The vocational institute graduates have been trained at heavy public subsidy specially to undertake industrial employment and I am, therefore, naturally perturbed lest doubts about their value should take hold. No effort has been spared to explain to the public, through the mass media and other means, the many developments which have taken place in industrial training since 1968. Any misconceptions and prejudices which still persist, even among a small sector of the population, could be very damaging.

    The best way to stamp out these unfavourable attitudes and to ensure that training programmes receive the fullest acceptance and recognition is to develop close co-operation between the Government, industry and labour. The growth of such co-operation will become increasingly necessary in the next stage of industrial training, as it is envisaged that the further skill-development of the basic-trained worker can most effectively be undertaken by and within industry. It is for these reasons that an Industrial Training Board is being proposed to centralise, co-ordinate and intensify industrial training. A statutory board will enable industry and labour to participate more fully towards common goals. It will have more flexibility in an area where slowness to respond to changing conditions can result in high training wastage on the one hand and critical skill shortages on the other. A board will also be better able to deal with the problems of disseminating the right kind of conceptions about industrial training.

    When the responsibility for industrial training becomes vested in the Board, technical education in schools will remain the responsibility of the Ministry. The Technical Education Department, with all its functions taken over, will then be dissolved.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, this Bill is essentially a straightforward Bill. Its main purpose has already been outlined in the Explanatory

Column: 369

Statement, and I do not wish to go into the details again.

    While industrial training is primarily the responsibility of industry, it is imperative to ensure that national interests are served. A major function of the Board will be to encourage industry to play its proper role in the national industrial training effort.

    It is envisaged that the future pattern of industrial training to be promoted by the Industrial Training Board will be as follows: -

    (1) The training of operatives and artisans will gradually be transferred back to industry.

    (2) On the other hand, the further development of the necessary training capacity for the required output of skilled manpower, both institutionally and within industry, will be a major preoccupation of the Board.

    (3) The Board will increase the supply of persons institutionally trained up to Trade Certificate and Industrial Technician Certificate levels.

    (4) The further skill-development of the basic-trained worker will be accomplished by the employer with the help of the Board through on-the-job training and, wherever possible, within the framework of an apprenticeship training scheme.

    (5) The emphasis in industrial training will be placed on the attainment of recognised standards. The Government envisages that the Industrial Training Board will develop a national system of trade testing. This will not only improve the quality of training but also establish uniformity of standards within the work-force.

    (6) The upgrading of adult skilled workers will be progressively achieved through programmes of off-the-job Industrial Training (OJIT), based on the module system already introduced.

    (7) To cater for the smaller industries, group training schemes, encompassing both apprenticeship training and OJIT, will be developed for the upgrading of key personnel, and finally,

Column: 370



    (8) The promotion of apprenticeship training itself will be a primary concern of the Board.

    It will be apparent, from what I have just outlined, that apprenticeship schemes will feature increasingly in industrial training. The Government is giving consideration to introducing legislation to promote and regulate apprenticeship training at some future date. The Government will look forward to the views and recommendations of the Industrial Training Board, when formed, on the detailed provisions that will be necessary. It is anticipated that the legislation will cover the definition of apprenticeable trades, the forms and conduct of the training to be undertaken, and the responsibilities of both employer and apprentice, including the period of indenture. The Industrial Training Board will then become the chief agency for the implementation of apprenticeship training.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

3.08 p.m.

    Mr Sia Khoon Seong (Moulmein): Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to inquire from the Minister for Education as to when will the Industrial Training Board be actually set up, now that the Bill is being read a Second and Third time. What are the present educational institutions that will be taken over by the Industrial Training Board? Will they be only the vocational institutes? Will they include the technical schools, the centralised workshops, and so on? What categories of teachers will be given the opportunity to exercise their option to he employed by the Industrial Training Board, and whether the terms and conditions of service will be as favourable, if not, more favourable than what they are at present?

    In respect of clause 19 (h) of the Bill which states that the Industrial Training Board can carry on any trade or business, I would like to request the Minister for Education to elaborate on what trade or business that he envisages the Industrial Training Board will carry

Column: 371

out. Will this affect the training programme of the educational institutions? There is also a provision in clause 39 which makes it compulsory for apprentices who undergo training to be insured. I would like to know whether consideration is also given to teachers to be insured also.

    There is provision for teachers to exercise the option as to whether or not they want to remain in the Government service or to be opted in to the Industrial Training Board. In this respect can the Minister for Education ensure that a reasonable period will be given to the teachers to exercise the option, so that they can have a clearer picture of what their future will be when they opt? As at present, they are still vague about their working conditions.

3.12 p.m.

    Mr J. F. Conceicao (Katong): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I heartily commend the Government on the introduction of this Bill. I have no doubts that the effect of the establishment of a properly administered Industrial Training Board will be a vastly improved co-ordination of all industrial training which at present seems to be in a relatively fragmented state. It can also be expected that industrial training facilities will be improved and extended. It is significant that research and assistance in research will feature as a function of the Industrial Training Board. Thus, Sir, we can expect a more systematic and rational relationship between training and the industrial training needs that can result from a better understanding of training problems.

    We have been told that there will be a determination of common standards to be attained in different industrial skills and a common method of ascertaining whether these standards have indeed been attained. The problem that arises is how to encourage industries, especially the small ones to which the Minister has already made reference, to organise training for their own apprentices up to the standard set by the Industrial

Column: 372

Training Board, or to see to the building of the skills of employees in small industries. Obviously, incentives will have to be provided. It is only realistic to conclude that many enterprises will have to be induced to take advantage of the apprenticeship training provisions, although the better the skills of the workers, the better the chances of an enterprise succeeding. Of course, the beneficiary will be the industry itself.

    This reminds me of the problem that we are having over quality control. It is no use pointing out that quality control makes for profitability. There has to be a demonstration effect. Incentives have to be offered. In the case of the Industrial Training Board, in as much as there has been talk of payroll tax being used to support apprenticeship and industrial training, I would support such a measure. Indeed, perhaps an additional eventual measure will have to be provided, as what the Minister has already referred to, namely, the passage of an apprenticeship training act which will make it compulsory for industries to provide training according to schedules, schemes and conditions laid down by the Industrial Training Board.

    Apparently, the Industrial Training Board will have to work out the manner in which those industries which already have general training may be able to contribute to industrial training. NATIONAL CADET CORPS BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

3.28 p.m.

    The Minister for Education (Dr Lee Chiaw Meng): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Sir, the Cadet Corps movement in Singapore was founded in 1902 when the first Army Cadet Corps units were formed in Raffles Institution. It was

Column: 376

only after the Second World War that the movement gained momentum. In 1947, Army Cadet Corps units were resuscitated; in 1948 the Sea Cadet Corps was formed, followed in 1949 by the formation of the Air Training Corps. Each of these organisations functioned independently of the other. With independence in 1965, the need to inculcate the youth of the Republic with a sense of patriotism and to develop in them ruggedness of mind and body and leadership qualities became imperative. It was considered that an effective way of bringing this about lay in the training provided by the uniformed movement in the schools. An expansion programme of the Cadet Corps movement was therefore embarked upon in 1965. The combined membership of the three Cadet Corps then stood at just over 1,500 with 24 schools participating. Today, the strength of the Cadet Corps has risen to over 14,000 members (9,000 boys and 5,000 girls) with 102 out of 113 secondary schools participating. Next year, the Cadet Corps membership is expected to reach 18,000.

    Membership in the Cadet Corps extends from Secondary I to Pre-University I students. It is no exaggeration to say that many of our top Singapore Armed Forces personnel once served as cadets when they were in school. I am informed that cadets, on becoming national servicemen, have acquitted themselves well, setting high standards in discipline, bearing, turnout and performances. That the Cadet Corps provides sound pre-national service training is no modest claim.

    With increasing numbers of students wishing to join the Cadet Corps, at one time the movement was faced with the difficulty of training sufficient numbers of officers to meet new demands and to replace those leaving the Corps on promotion, transfers, secondment, study leave and resignations. However, the problem is gradually being overcome with the introduction of cadet training at the Teachers Training College. Last June, 36 TTC trainees graduated as qualified teachers as well as trained

Column: 377

cadet officers. Currently, there are 99 final year TTC students undergoing cadet training. Steps are being taken to relieve the shortage of officers in the Cadet Corps through the appointments of SAF reservists who are teachers. Attention is paid to Pre-U I students who are given advanced training for appointment as Cadet Lieutenants.

    The expansion of the Cadet Corps movement necessitated a complete review of the Cadet Corps organisation as a whole. Hence on 1st January, 1969, the National Cadet Corps was formed by the integration of the Army, Sea and Air Cadet Corps to strengthen the administration of the Cadet Corps movement and to raise the level of training of all cadets in schools. This move ensures that the best use is made of manpower, buildings, training areas and facilities and of other logistical requirements, resulting in maximum utilisation of available resources. With this integration, new legislation has to be promulgated to replace the existing Acts and Regulations which govern the Army, Sea and Air Cadet Corps separately. Hence the introduction of the National Cadet Corps Bill. In passing, I would like to mention that the Police Cadet Corps does not form part of the National Cadet Corps. It remains under the control of the Ministry of Home Affairs. However, steps are being taken to update the Police Cadet Corps Act and the Police Cadet Corps Regulations to bring them in line with the main provisions of the National Cadet Corps Act and Regulations.

    With the enactment of the National Cadet Corps Bill, the Cadet Corps will be accorded the status befitting the role it is playing in training our youth to become loyal and responsible citizens as part of our effort to build an organised and disciplined society.

    Sir, I beg to move.
